description: From Medieval Latin allocāte, imperative of Latin allocāre, from ad- (“to”) + locus (“place”).

verbs.description: allocate (third-person singular simple present allocates, present participle allocating, simple past and past participle allocated)

entries.meaning: To set aside for a purpose.
examples: Synonyms: appropriate, earmark; see also Thesaurus:set apart
Please do not eat the meringue, as it is allocated for the dinner party tomorrow.

entries.meaning: To distribute according to a plan, generally followed by the adposition to.
examples: The bulk of K–12 education funds are allocated to school districts that in turn pay for the cost of operating schools.

entries.meaning: (computing) To reserve a portion of memory for use by a computer program.
